Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: An HOA inspection is scheduled and items left in the corridor could be cited for blocking an emergency exit.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: This morning, I was rushing to get ready for my volunteer shift at the community food pantry. I’m the only one with the keys today, and I know there’s already a line forming outside. If I’m late, people will be left waiting in the cold, and the whole schedule will be thrown off. As I grabbed my bag, I noticed my neighbor’s stroller and a couple of boxes cluttering the corridor outside our apartment. The HOA inspection is today, and anything blocking the hallway could get us all cited. I know I should knock on their door and ask them to move their things, or at least help clear the space myself. But every minute I spend here means more people waiting, and I can’t unlock the pantry from here. My mind races—do I risk upsetting my neighbors and possibly getting everyone in trouble, or do I risk letting down the people counting on me at the pantry? My heart pounds as I stand in the hallway, keys in hand, torn between two places I need to be.
